results.name: Smallest A (in absolute value) such that for p=prime(n), 2^{(p-1)/2} == +-1 + A*p (mod p^2), i.e., such that p is a near-Wieferich prime.
comment: p is in A001220 iff a(n) == 0. This is the case iff A014664(n) == A243905(n), which happens for n = 183 and n = 490.
Is a(n) == 0 for any other n, and, if yes, are there infinitely many such n?
link: Felix Fröhlich, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000
R. Crandall, K. Dilcher and C. Pomerance, A search for Wieferich and Wilson primes, Math. Comp., 66 (1997), 433-449.
program: apply(p->a(0,p), primes(100)[2..100]) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jun 15 2015
